race.name: Cedar Blitz
race.tagline: West Michigan gravel in Cedar Springs near Grand Rapids.

climate.description: Summer conditions with potential for heat.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through west Michigan. Rolling terrain with moderate elevation.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Small grassroots west Michigan event. Affordable and near Grand Rapids but limited infrastructure.

biased_opinion.summary: Cedar Blitz is a small grassroots gravel race in west Michigan near Grand Rapids. The proximity to Grand Rapids gives it better access than some rural events, but it's still a small regional race with basic organization and limited field depth. It's an honest local event with rolling terrain and affordable pricing for Michigan cyclists.
weaknesses: Small field with no competitive depth
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A small local gravel race in west Michigan. Perfect for locals or Grand Rapids area cyclists who want an affordable summer ride. Not worth traveling far for.

final_verdict.one_liner: Small grassroots west Michigan ride near Grand Rapids.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Only if you're in west Michigan or the Grand Rapids area and want an affordable gravel ride. Not worth traveling for.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Michigan events: Barry-Roubaix, Lumberjack 100. For similar grassroots vibes: other regional Midwest events.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Cedar Springs has basic lodging. Grand Rapids (30 min) has more options.
logistics.food: Small city with dining options. Stock race nutrition beforehand.

history.origin_story: Grassroots gravel event in west Michigan.

course_description.character: Rolling west Michigan gravel through rural areas.
course_description.signature_challenge: Rolling west Michigan terrain and summer heat.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 62 miles of west Michigan gravel near Grand Rapids.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Small grassroots event in Cedar Springs.

logistics.explanation: Downtown Cedar Springs start/finish at the brewery creates centralized logistics with post-race festival atmosphere. Tracy Gravlin confirms the payoff: "The tasty Cedar Springs Ale was our reward! We both are going home with a growler." Holiday Inn lodging keeps accommodations simple.

length.explanation: Four distance options from 18-mile beginner to 130-mile ultra hit the right spread. Tracy Gravlin's 50-mile experience shows proper mid-race challenge: "The start was fast and felt great. About 26 miles in, the head winds seemed to be everywhere you turned."

technicality.explanation: Beth Huffaker describes the course as "fast, no chunky gravel and no giant hills" - flowing rather than punishing through Michigan farmland. The terrain favors speed over technical bike handling through "beautiful farm country" without sustained climbing challenges.

elevation.explanation: Rider reports confirm "no giant hills" through the 3000 feet of elevation over 62 miles. Michigan's glacial terrain delivers rolling farmland without sustained climbs - punchy but manageable, creating fatigue through repetition rather than epic ascents.

climate.explanation: Wind becomes the primary weather challenge rather than temperature extremes. Tracy Gravlin experienced significant "head winds everywhere you turned" starting around mile 26, making solo riding particularly difficult through the exposed farm country sections.

altitude.explanation: Cedar Springs sits at standard Midwest elevation well under 1000 feet. No altitude effects or thin air challenges - just Great Lakes region farmland where humidity creates more breathing difficulty than oxygen deprivation.

adventure.explanation: The 130-mile ultra offers true adventure with GPS navigation, mandatory lights, and complete self-support through unmarked terrain. Shorter distances stick to well-marked routes with full support - safe but predictable through rural Michigan forests.

prestige.explanation: Growing regional reputation as "one of the fastest growing gravel races in the region" but limited national draw. Field depth remains thin - Tracy Gravlin notes "Beth and I were the only women in the 60+" category, highlighting minimal competitive depth.

race_quality.explanation: Dragon Adventures Base Camp describes it as a "well-organized, high-energy gravel race" with proper timing and aid stations. The race proceeds in most weather conditions with director discretion for severe storms, maintaining consistent execution.

experience.explanation: Post-race atmosphere delivers festival vibes downtown. Dragon Adventures Base Camp captured it perfectly: "The post-race hangout, and great local food made the finish line feel like a festival" with craft beer and community celebration at Cedar Springs Brewery.

community.explanation: Strong community building draws riders nationally â€” "The BaseCamp community has given me so many cycling friends from across the country. Beth came up from Kansas!" Downtown brewery finish creates town square atmosphere with 500+ riders in 2024, making it "one of the fastest growing gravel races in the region."

field_depth.explanation: Participatory rather than competitive depth. Tracy Gravlin's observation that "we came in ahead of the 50-59 and one of the 40-49" from the thin 60+ field shows limited age group participation across categories.

value.explanation: Four distance options with full support, timing, medical coverage, and downtown festival atmosphere deliver strong value. The complete package covers "beginner-friendly routes to leg-burning challenges" with post-race craft beer celebration included.

expenses.explanation: Cedar Springs location keeps costs reasonable with Holiday Inn standard pricing and downtown brewery logistics avoiding expensive shuttles. Rural Michigan setting maintains accessibility for regional travel without big-city event pricing inflation.
